p: A few recent papers have modelled the impact of ETSs on shipping costs (Gu et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2015; Zhu et al., 2018), with the rather expected conclusion that results depend primarily on the bunker price as well as whether the system is open or closed, i.e. if permits can be traded outside the sector or outside the ETS. According to Psaraftis (2021), EU ETS permits purchased by the shipping sector will be fully tradeable within the scheme like other permits. Christodoulou et al. (2021) demonstrated the differential effects on various maritime trades, whereby smaller vessels such as RoRo ferries transporting trailers would be more disadvantaged than large oil tankers with higher economies of scale, potentially leading to a reverse modal shift towards road for intra-EU container and trailer traffic. Cariou et al. (2021) found that the cost increase on shipping could be enough to incentivise energy reduction measures such as wind assistance technologies.
